body:
Let's do multiple PRs:
* [x] add tests into `integration_tests`, create some arrays, test the result (perhaps using `sum`), enable gfortran, do single and nested (double, triple) implied do loops; do both in print, as well as in array constructors `[(...)]`, both in statements and in declarations (#984)
* [x] AST->ASR, add the `DoLoopExpr` node, and test those `integration_tests` in `tests/tests.toml`. (#994)
* [ ] Either ASR->LLVM implementation or ASR->ASR passes implementation; The ASR->ASR pass implementation might work by creating a pure function that returns an array, and inside the function we simply do a regular `DoLoop`.

issue.title: Compile minpack

labels.name: SciPy
labels.description: issues related to enable LFortran to compile the entire FORTRAN codebase in SciPy

issue.body:
### TODO to public a blog post

* [x] add CI: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/1182
* [ ] get rid of all the three "XX" commits in the minpack repo (by fixing it in LFortran)
* [ ] get all examples working
* [ ] should run at our CI correctly for a few weeks to reach "beta" (ideally 2 months, but we can "overwrite" this requirement)
* [ ] write up a blog post and announce

### Tracking examples
- [x] examples_hybrd
- [x] examples_hybrd1
- [ ] examples_lmder1
   - #1150 
   - #1133
- [x] examples_lmdif1
  - #1122
- [ ] examples_primes
   - #967 


---------




### Highest Priority

The code now compiles to binary (with just minimal source modifications, see below), but doesn't produce correct answers due to:

* [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/971 (fixed by #972)
* [x] https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/976

And perhaps other issues that we have not identified yet.

---------

### AST->ASR

These must be fixed, but the workaround is relatively simple by modifying Minpack sources, so are lower priority than the above.

Known TODO items for ASR (we commented out code for now):

* [ ] equivalence statement
* [x] statement functions (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/911)
* [x] implicit external (#950)
* [ ] implied do loop (#981)
* [x] do loop non-constant integer increment (#909, #946, #979)
* [x] argument callback (undeclared)
* [x] external function declared as "double precision f", when it should probably be "external f"
* [x] implicit interface failure
* [ ] LFortran also prints several warnings for missing features that are ignored, so we have to fix those
* [x] The -I and -J options (https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/930)
* [ ] `format()`: this is not strictly needed to get the correct answer and might not even be needed for SciPy, but it would be good to have it, so that things format on the screen correctly


---------------

Steps:

https://github.com/certik/minpack/tree/scipy

```console
git clone https://github.com/certik/minpack.git
cd minpack
git checkout -t origin/scipy
FC=lfortran cmake .
make
ctest
```

All files compile to ASR as of 04d5732088ba195865ee9ccf322a4eea55070424, and when compiled sequentially, there is a failure in the LLVM backend:
```console
$ make

[  8%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/hybipt.f.o
[ 10%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o
Internal Compiler Error: Unhandled exception
Traceback (most recent call last):

    result = fe.get_asr2(input, lm, diagnostics);

    compiler_options.symtab_only, compiler_options);
```

which is a slight regression caused by #864. As of 8e41e7f7e (a slightly prior commit) the error is:
```console
$ make
[  2%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/minpack.f90.o
[  4%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/covar.f.o
[  6%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/errjac.f.o
[  8%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/hybipt.f.o
[ 10%] Building Fortran object src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o
semantic error: Object type ArrayItem is not implemented yet.
  --> /Users/ondrej/repos/lfortran/minpack/src/lhesfcn.f:64:12
   |
64 |       data y(1),y(2),y(3),y(4),y(5),y(6),y(7),y(8),y(9),y(10),y(11),
   |            ^^^^ 


Note: if any of the above error or warning messages are not clear or are lacking
context please report it to us (we consider that a bug that needs to be fixed).
make[2]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/lhesfcn.f.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [src/CMakeFiles/minpack.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2
```
Which shows where the issue is.



----------------

*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/664

It would be very useful to have LFortran able to compile Minpack, currently it fails with commit 74d6438a8

```
❯ lfortran --version
LFortran version: 0.14.0-1345-g74d6438a8
Platform: Linux
Default target: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
❯ fpm build --compiler lfortran
minpack.f90                            failed.
[   7%]Compiling...
semantic error: Value of a parameter variable must evaluate to a compile time constant
  --> ././src/minpack.f90:20:5
   |
20 |     real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = dpmpar(1) !! the machine precision
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 


Note: if any of the above error or warning messages are not clear or are lacking
context please report it to us (we consider that a bug that needs to be fixed).
```

With a minor patch:

```diff
diff --git a/src/minpack.f90 b/src/minpack.f90
index 65fe5b1..ad60201 100644
--- a/src/minpack.f90
+++ b/src/minpack.f90
@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ module minpack_module
                                                    tiny(1.0_wp), &
                                                    huge(1.0_wp)] !! machine constants
 
-    real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = dpmpar(1) !! the machine precision
+    real(wp), parameter, private :: epsmch = epsilon(1.0_wp) !! the machine precision
     real(wp), parameter, private :: one = 1.0_wp
     real(wp), parameter, private :: zero = 0.0_wp
 
```

I'm getting an error for the procedure pointer

```
❯ fpm build --compiler lfortran
minpack.f90                            failed.
[   7%]Compiling...
semantic error: Type not implemented yet.
   --> ./src/minpack.f90:438:9
    |
438 |         procedure(func) :: fcn !! the user-supplied subroutine which
    |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 


```

body: Perfect. Now construct `DoLoopExpr` appropriately when the AST->ASR translation encounters implied do loop.

See https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/pull/985#discussion_r1014643860, it looks like we already do everything we planned to do. :) That's even better. So now just see why the implied do loops do not work in Minpack, mabye it's some ASR->ASR pass.
Yeah, on it.

I am unable to find use of `ImpliedDoLoop` node in ASR of files of minpack (explicitly). (Looking into it.)

For `integration_tests/implied_do_loop2.f90`, latest main shows the following error
```
semantic error: reshape only accept arrays for shape arguments, found i32 instead.
 --> /home/pranavchiku/lfortran/integration_tests/implied_do_loops2.f90:4:10
  |
4 |  array = reshape([(i,(i+j,j=1,4),i=1,3)], shape(array))
  |          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

```
See here: https://github.com/certik/minpack/commit/123becc96d9d90f5b01a204abbe1052b3ce00cf8

I guess we need to implement `visit_ImpliedDoLoop()` in `ast_symboltable_visitor`, it is currently only in `ast_body_visitor`.

So going with our TODO list: https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/981#issuecomment-1302328560, it seems the step 2. is done (AST->ASR always works?). You mentioned `ast_symboltable_visitor`, is there something that doesn't work there?

The last step is the number 3: "The ASR->ASR pass implementation might work by creating a pure function that returns an array, and inside the function we simply do a regular DoLoop.".

>You mentioned ast_symboltable_visitor, is there something that doesn't work there?

Yeah it looks like that we are missing `visit_ImpliedDoLoop()` implementation in `ast_symboltable_visitor`.

Can you show an example program that triggers such a problem?

It seems we don't need that for Minpack at least.

If I undo the changes of this [commit](https://github.com/certik/minpack/commit/123becc96d9d90f5b01a204abbe1052b3ce00cf8) at minpack, 

It gives the following [log](https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/981#issuecomment-1304721999)

In that log you can see the error is from `asr_to_llvm`:
```
  File "/home/pranavchiku/lfortran/src/libasr/codegen/asr_to_llvm.cpp", line 3831, in LFortran::ASRToLLVMVisitor::visit_expr_wrapper(LFortran::ASR::expr_t const*, bool)
    this->visit_expr(*x);
```

issue.title: Fixes in `ImpliedDoLoop`.
issue.body: This PR solves  [#981 (comment) ](https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/981#issuecomment-1304725752), AST->ASR passes for ImpliedDoLoop works.

body:
I see. Yes, that's one issue.

The other issue is in asr_to_llvm, where indeed the visitor is not implemented yet, so it fails.

Along with that when we encounter ImpliedDoLoop ex: `(i,i=1,3)` here in `lfortran` we need to have `integer::i` declared, else it shows `variable i not declared` error, whereas in `gfortran` it works without explicitly declaring variable i

Okay so, with #994 step2 is done.(to the best of my knowledge)

If you could brief me about implementing asr_to_llvm, that would be of great help.

> If you could brief me about implementing asr_to_llvm, that would be of great help.

https://github.com/lfortran/lfortran/issues/981#issuecomment-1304723176

Do I need to follow the implementation of `function` as present in `visit_Function` of `asr_to_llvm.cpp`? or should I proceed the way I did in `ast_common_visitor.cpp`?

I am confused about the syntax of the implementation, the logic is clear.

I am thinking the easiest way to implement this is to create an ASR pass that transforms ImpliedDoLoop into a function call that just calls a regular loop. That way we don't need to touch any of the backends.

So what remains is the ASR->ASR pass. Roughly speaking, it will take a code like this:
```fortran
program test_a
implicit none
integer :: x(6), i
x = [(i*2, i = 1, 6)]
print *, x
end program
```
and transform it into:
```fortran
program test_b
implicit none
integer :: x(6)
x = implied_do_loop_01()
print *, x

contains

    pure function implied_do_loop_01() result(x)
    integer :: x(6), i
    do i = 1, 6
        x(i) = i*2
    end do
    end function

end program
```

That is one use case.  This will also automatically work for things like:
```fortran
program test_a
implicit none
integer :: i
print *, [(i*2, i = 1, 6)]
end program
```

The other use case is this one:
```fortran
program test_a
implicit none
integer :: i
print *, (i*2, i = 1, 6)
end program
```
which I am not sure is equivalent to the previous case (especially with regards to formatting, which we have not implemented yet). I think to be on the safe side, this case is equivalent to:
```fortran
program test_a
implicit none
integer :: i
print *, 1*2, 2*2, 3*2, 4*2, 5*2, 6*2
end program
```


In the implied do loop pass, it can handle both cases. It is going over every ImpliedDoLoop, if it is wrapped in an ArrayConstant, it will the do first kind (and since we do not need this in Minpack, we can just keep the original code in there for now), and if ImpliedDoLoop is part of a Print statement, we will transform the print statement to the above last example.

Note: this will not work for this case:
```fortran
program test_a
implicit none
integer :: i, n
n = 10
print *, (i*2, i = 1, n)
end program
```
So indeed, it looks like we might need to use the first approach.
